story_title: When NYC First Lit Up the Night Sky
original_story: [excited] Get this—on September 4, 1882, New York City flipped the switch on its first commercial power plant! Thomas Edison’s Pearl Street Station lit up the streets, transforming the dark with electric lights. Imagine the thrill of seeing bright bulbs glowing in the night for the first time ever! This groundbreaking moment marked the dawn of the electric age, leading to the electrification of homes and businesses. In just a few years, nearly 90% of NYC would be powered by electricity. Crazy, right?

synchronized_prompts.image_prompt: Wide shot of bustling New York City streets on September 4, 1882, illuminated by the first electric lights from Edison's Pearl Street Station. The glowing bulbs cast dramatic shadows, showcasing astonished faces of onlookers, capturing the electrifying moment as the darkness transforms into a vibrant spectacle.

Wide shot of New York City at night, 1882, with the first electric lights illuminating bustling streets. Eager crowds gaze in awe at glowing bulbs, casting sharp shadows and creating a dramatic atmosphere. The Pearl Street Station stands proudly in the background, symbolizing innovation.
